comments:
GLA does not continuously monitor correctly log files that wrap with large log 
records.

For example, if a log file contains log records with static content greater 
than 1024 bytes at the end of the log record, the GLA does not retrieve newly 
create log records when continuously monitoring the log file.

Paul,

This doesn't make 100% sence to me.  The sensor has no notion of records, it 
only looks at raw bites.  The confidence buffer (which is only 1024) today is 
used to determine whether the file has been appended/reeplaced/etc.  Can you 
give a few more details so I can hunt down the cause of the problem?  Thanks.

This is a corner case when log records are quite large.  When monitoring log 
files with large amounts of static data at the end of the record (e.g. the 
dynamic data such as time stamps are at the beginning of the log record), the 
GLA never determines that new records are being added.  For example, multiple 
writes of the follow record (e.g. new time stamp) are not being sensed:

ExtendedMessage:

We already partly handle this scenario with the use of a historic confidence 
buffer and a footer size.  I am going to expose these additional attributes in 
the schema and hense in the UI.  This allows the user to write rulest hat 
bypass this problem.

Eugene,  I have completed the changes in the runtime to honour the 
confidenceBufferSize and fileFooterSize.  These attributes are now part of the 
schema.  Can you take care of re-genning the UI?  Once this is complete this 
defect should go to nellie so she can add the docs for these two attributes.

Richard, I am done with the model and UI changes, can you please refresh with 
the latest cvs code and verify the changes.
Please then pass this to Nellie if everything is good to you.
Thanks.
Added details for this to the GLA docs.
